newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk army in "life or death" fight with Islamists.
newsitem.headline: Turk army in "life or death" fight with Islamists.

text.p: A leading Turkish general on Tuesday said the armed forces' struggle against Islamist activities was vital to the survival of the secular republic.

"Destroying fundamentalism is of life or death importance," General Kenan Deniz told a special briefing for journalists to lay out the military's position in its row with the government of Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan.

The general also blasted neighbouring Iran, with whom Erbakan has made a special effort to patch up strained ties, for seeking to undermine Turkey by providing overt support for the separatist Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK).

"Iran... is continuing with its efforts to destroy the regime in the Turkish republic," said Deniz, a leader in the security forces' fight with the PKK. "It is known to have directed terrorist actions in Turkey."
The general's tough talk follows weeks of mounting tensions between the armed forces, traditional defenders of Turkey's secularist system, and Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader.

On Saturday, Erbakan reluctantly agreed to demands from the army for a series of anti-Islamist measures, but his Islam-based Welfare Party has made it clear it was not prepared to go along with reforms that would close Koranic schools.
Turkey's generals have toppled three civilian governments since 1960, but have been content in recent weeks to only hint at possible intervention this time around.
The ensuing crisis has sent political leaders scrambling to find a new government formula to exclude Erbakan. It has also put renewed pressure on Turkish markets.
